key_points: Former Officer Derek Chauvin knelt on George Floyd for 9 minutes and 29 seconds, according to prosecutors.
The 9:29 timing corrects the previously thought duration of 8:46, which became a symbol of police brutality.
Prosecuting attorney Jerry Blackwell highlighted the significance of the 9:29 timing in his opening statements.
The kneeling time was broken down into three sections, showing Floyd's distress and eventual non-responsiveness.
Chauvin's defense accepts the revised timing and argues it supports their case.
The altercation in the trial was less about the timing difference and more about the extensive evidence presented.
The 8:46 timing has become culturally significant, inspiring protests, moments of silence, and creative works.
Despite the change in timing, the earlier 8:46 duration has been widely commemorated, including by Floyd's family.
The Hennepin County Attorney's Office has corrected the timing on several occasions.
Initial errors in reporting the duration were attributed to the timing of viral bystander video.
